bibl.title: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Hugh S. Cumming, October 1, 1925

div1.p: Ravenel does not agree that Carter's work led Reed to investigate into mosquito transmission of yellow fever, pointing to earlier contributions to the theory by Nott and Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Hugh S. Cumming, October 1, 1925
div1.opener:
Copy.
University of Missouri
Columbia.
Biographic (?)
Rio. Ravenel, M.
October 1, 1925.
Bacteriology and Preventive Medicine.
Surgeon General H. SC. Cumming,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
My Dear General Cumming:
div1.p:
I am very much obliged to you for the mimeographed copy of the not-
ice concerning Dr. Carter, some of which I am incorporating into a review
of his life already written. I wish I could agree with you that it was Car-
ter's work that led Reed to investigate the mosquito transmission of yel- !
low fever. It is well known that Nott in 1848 maintained this theory and
thought hethat he had proved it. His article was published in the New Or-
leans Medical Journal. It is equally well known that Carlos Finlay held the
same theory, believing that he had proved it, and out of the six or seven
hundred mosquitoes found in Cuba, had selected the correct one. I had a
letter yesterday from Colonel Jefferson R. Kean, in which he says that it
is his recollection that Reed had decided to investigate the question of
mosquito transmission before he left the United States. General Sternberg
authorized him to make this investigation, but told him that he thought it
would be a waste of time.

I would be the last one to detract from Carter's work, but I am more
interested in the truth of medical history than I am in boosting any one
particular man.
div1.closer:
With much respect, I am,
Very sincerely yours, (Signed) Mazÿck P. Ravenel, M. D. MPR:LP
